content.headline: Your Guide to 5 Weeks Pregnant: A Journey Begins!
content.intro: Week 5 marks the beginning of your second month of pregnancy and is often when many women realize they've missed a period and start to experience early symptoms. This is an exciting time of rapid development for your baby and significant hormonal shifts for you! Take a deep breath—you are already doing amazing things!

sections.title: The Baby: Development at 5 Weeks
sections.content: At 5 weeks pregnant, your baby (now called an embryo) is the size of a sesame seed (about 2mm). Major development is underway:
points: Neural tube forming - will become brain and spinal cord
Tiny heart begins beating and circulating blood
Foundations for major organs developing
Placenta and umbilical cord starting to function

sections.title: Your Body: What to Expect at 5 Weeks
sections.content: Your body is adapting to pregnancy hormones (hCG and progesterone):
points: Fatigue - your body is working hard building the placenta
Morning sickness (can happen any time of day)
Tender, swollen breasts
Frequent urination
Food cravings/aversions and heightened smell

sections.title: Important Steps This Week
points: Take a pregnancy test - hCG levels are now detectable
Schedule your first prenatal appointment
Continue healthy habits: avoid alcohol, limit caffeine
Listen to your body and rest when needed

content.headline: Essential Nutrition for a Healthy Pregnancy
content.intro: Eating a healthy diet during pregnancy helps support your baby's growth and development while keeping you energized and strong. Good nutrition is one of the best gifts you can give your growing baby!

sections.title: Key Nutrients You Need
sections.content: Focus on these essential nutrients for a healthy pregnancy:
points: Folic acid: Prevents neural tube defects (600-800 mcg daily)
Calcium: Builds strong bones and teeth (1,000 mg daily)
Iron: Supports blood production for you and baby (27 mg daily)
Protein: Essential for baby's growth (71 grams daily)
Vitamin D: Promotes bone health (600 IU daily)

sections.title: Foods to Emphasize
sections.content: Include these nutrient-rich foods in your daily diet:
points: Whole grains: Oatmeal, whole wheat bread, brown rice
Lean proteins: Chicken, fish, eggs, beans, lentils
Dairy: Milk, yogurt, cheese for calcium
Fruits & vegetables: Colorful variety for vitamins
Healthy fats: Avocado, nuts, olive oil

sections.title: Foods to Limit or Avoid
sections.content: Some foods require extra caution during pregnancy:
points: Limit caffeine to less than 200 mg per day
Avoid raw or undercooked seafood, eggs, and meat
Skip unpasteurized dairy products and juices
Avoid high-mercury fish like shark and swordfish
Limit processed foods high in sugar and salt

sections.title: Managing Common Pregnancy Issues
points: For nausea: Eat small, frequent meals and dry crackers
For constipation: Drink plenty of water and eat high-fiber foods
For heartburn: Avoid spicy foods and eat smaller meals
For food aversions: Find alternative nutrient sources
Always take prenatal vitamins as recommended

articles.title: Signs Your Body is Adjusting to Pregnancy

content.headline: Recognizing Your Body's Pregnancy Changes
content.intro: Pregnancy brings remarkable physical and hormonal changes as your body adapts to support your growing baby. Understanding these normal adjustments can help you feel more confident and prepared for each stage of this incredible journey.

sections.title: Early Pregnancy Changes (First Trimester)
sections.content: Your body begins significant transformations from the very beginning:
points: Missed period - often the first noticeable sign
Fatigue and increased need for rest
Nausea with or without vomiting (morning sickness)
Tender, swollen breasts and darker areolas
Frequent urination as uterus expands
Food cravings or aversions to certain smells

sections.title: Mid-Pregnancy Adjustments (Second Trimester)
sections.content: Many early symptoms ease while new changes emerge:
points: Visible baby bump as uterus grows upward
Feeling baby movements (quickening)
Skin changes like linea nigra and glow
Round ligament pain as uterus expands
Nasal congestion and occasional nosebleeds
Improved energy levels typically return

sections.title: Late Pregnancy Transformations (Third Trimester)
sections.content: Your body prepares for childbirth and breastfeeding:
points: Shortness of breath as baby pushes diaphragm
Braxton Hicks contraction practice
Increased back pain and pelvic pressure
Swelling in ankles and feet
Colostrum production in breasts
Nesting instinct and preparation urges

sections.title: When to Contact Your Healthcare Provider
points: Severe or persistent abdominal pain
Heavy bleeding or fluid leakage
Severe headaches or vision changes
Significant swelling in hands/face
Decreased fetal movement after 28 weeks
Fever over 38°C or signs of infection

content.headline: Postpartum Self-Care: Nurturing Yourself After Birth
content.intro: The postpartum period is a transformative time that requires special attention to your physical and emotional recovery. Taking care of yourself isn't selfish—it's essential for your wellbeing and your ability to care for your newborn. Remember, a healthy mom means a healthy baby!

sections.title: Physical Recovery Essentials
sections.content: Your body needs time and care to heal after childbirth. Be patient and listen to your body's signals:
points: Rest whenever possible - sleep when your baby sleeps
Manage pain with prescribed medications and warm baths
Eat nutritious meals and stay hydrated
Care for your perineal area with proper hygiene
Watch for signs of infection and contact your provider if concerned

sections.title: Emotional Wellbeing
sections.content: Hormonal changes and new responsibilities can affect your emotional health:
points: Accept help from family and friends
Share your feelings with your partner or support person
Be patient with yourself - adjustment takes time
Watch for baby blues (common) vs postpartum depression (requires treatment)
Take breaks when needed - even 15 minutes alone can help

sections.title: Daily Self-Care Practices
points: Shower daily - it can boost your mood and energy
Wear comfortable clothes that make you feel good
Spend time outdoors when possible
Connect with other new parents for support
Keep water and healthy snacks nearby for easy access

articles.title: Caring for Yourself While Caring for Baby

content.headline: Balancing Your Needs While Nurturing Your Baby
content.intro: Caring for a newborn is demanding, but neglecting your own needs can lead to burnout. Finding balance between caring for your baby and yourself is crucial for sustainable parenting. You deserve care and attention too!

sections.title: Why Parent Self-Care Matters
sections.content: Taking care of yourself directly impacts your ability to care for your baby:
points: Reduced stress helps you respond more patiently to your baby
Better physical health means more energy for parenting
Emotional regulation models healthy coping for your child
Prevents caregiver burnout and exhaustion
Maintains your identity beyond being a parent

sections.title: Practical Self-Care Strategies
sections.content: Small, consistent practices can make a big difference in your wellbeing:
points: Take micro-breaks - even 5 minutes of deep breathing helps
Ask for help with household tasks and baby care
Connect with friends who understand your experience
Practice saying 'no' to unnecessary commitments
Keep a list of quick self-care activities for busy days

sections.title: Building a Support System
points: Identify trusted people who can provide practical help
Join parent groups for shared experiences and advice
Communicate your needs clearly to your partner
Consider professional support if feeling overwhelmed
Remember it's okay to not be perfect - good enough is great!

content.headline: Understanding Postpartum Mental Health
content.intro: The period after childbirth brings significant emotional changes. While many new parents experience temporary 'baby blues,' some may develop more serious conditions like postpartum depression. Recognizing the signs and seeking help early is crucial for your recovery and your baby's wellbeing.

sections.title: Common Postpartum Conditions
sections.content: Understanding the differences between normal adjustment and concerning symptoms:
points: Baby Blues: Mild mood swings, anxiety, sadness affecting 70-80% of new moms
Postpartum Depression: Persistent sadness, loss of interest, difficulty bonding
Postpartum Anxiety: Excessive worry, racing thoughts, physical anxiety symptoms
Postpartum OCD: Intrusive thoughts and compulsive behaviors
Postpartum Psychosis: Rare but serious condition requiring immediate care

sections.title: Warning Signs to Watch For
sections.content: These symptoms may indicate you need professional support:
points: Overwhelming sadness or crying spells
Severe mood swings or irritability
Difficulty bonding with your baby
Withdrawing from family and friends
Thoughts of harming yourself or your baby

sections.title: Getting Help and Treatment
points: Talk to your healthcare provider about your symptoms
Therapy and counseling can provide effective support
Medication may be recommended in some cases
Support groups connect you with others who understand
Emergency help is available if you have thoughts of self-harm

content.headline: Safe Return to Exercise After Pregnancy
content.intro: Returning to physical activity after childbirth requires patience and proper progression. While exercise can boost your energy and mood, it's important to start slowly and listen to your body's signals. Your recovery timeline is unique to you and your birth experience.

sections.title: When to Start Exercising
sections.content: Timing depends on your delivery and recovery:
points: Vaginal delivery: Often cleared at 4-6 weeks postpartum
C-section: Typically 6-8 weeks with provider clearance
Listen to your body - pain or bleeding means slow down
Start with gentle activities like walking first
Always get your provider's approval before beginning

sections.title: Safe Postpartum Exercises
sections.content: Begin with low-impact activities that support recovery:
points: Walking - start with short distances and gradually increase
Pelvic floor exercises (Kegels) for core recovery
Gentle stretching to improve flexibility
Deep breathing for core and relaxation
Modified strength training focusing on proper form

sections.title: Important Safety Considerations
points: Stop if you experience pain or increased bleeding
Wear supportive clothing, especially for breastfeeding moms
Stay hydrated and eat enough to support milk production
Be aware of diastasis recti (abdominal separation)
Progress gradually - this is a marathon, not a sprint!

content.headline: Essential Newborn Care: Evidence-Based Practices for Healthy Development
content.intro: Essential newborn care practices are critical interventions that can significantly reduce newborn mortality and improve infant health outcomes. Research from Ethiopia shows that proper newborn care utilization remains a challenge, with only about half of mothers practicing these essential techniques. Understanding and implementing these evidence-based practices can make a life-saving difference for your newborn.

sections.title: The Importance of Essential Newborn Care
sections.content: Globally, newborn deaths account for 46% of under-five deaths, with more than 80% resulting from preventable and treatable conditions. Research from Ethiopia shows that improving newborn care practices can significantly reduce infant mortality and improve long-term health outcomes.
points: Newborn deaths represent nearly half of all under-five mortality worldwide
Over 80% of newborn deaths are from preventable causes
Essential newborn care practices can reduce mortality by up to 50%
Proper care in the first 28 days is crucial for long-term development
Simple, cost-effective interventions can save millions of newborn lives

sections.title: Key Essential Newborn Care Practices
sections.content: These evidence-based practices form the foundation of healthy newborn development and should be implemented consistently:
points: Immediate and exclusive breastfeeding within first hour after birth
Proper thermal care and prevention of hypothermia
Hygienic cord care and infection prevention
Early recognition of danger signs and prompt care-seeking
Appropriate bathing timing and techniques
Skin-to-skin contact for temperature regulation and bonding

sections.title: Factors That Improve Newborn Care Utilization
sections.content: Research from Ethiopia identified key factors that significantly increase the likelihood of proper newborn care practices:
points: Postnatal care visits increase proper care by 5.5 times
Counseling during pregnancy and delivery improves practices 4.4 times
Regular antenatal care follow-up increases care utilization nearly 7 times
Maternal education improves care practices by 63%
Urban residence doubles the likelihood of proper newborn care

sections.title: Current Challenges and Solutions
sections.content: Despite the proven benefits, essential newborn care utilization faces several barriers that need addressing:
points: Only 48.77% of mothers in Ethiopia practice essential newborn care
Rural mothers face greater challenges accessing care information
Limited awareness about proper newborn care techniques
Inconsistent health facility services for newborn care
Need for targeted education during antenatal and postnatal visits

sections.title: Action Steps for Parents
points: Attend all antenatal and postnatal care appointments regularly
Seek comprehensive counseling during pregnancy and after delivery
Learn and practice proper breastfeeding techniques immediately after birth
Master thermal care and cord care procedures
Recognize danger signs that require immediate medical attention
Join educational programs focused on newborn care practices

content.headline: Developmental Milestones: Tracking Your Child's Growth from 2-5 Years
content.intro: Understanding developmental milestones helps parents track their child's progress and identify areas where they might need additional support. Each child develops at their own pace, but knowing typical milestones can provide reassurance and guidance for supporting healthy development across physical, social, language, and cognitive domains.

sections.title: Key Developmental Domains Explained
sections.content: Child development occurs across four main areas that work together to support overall growth and learning:
points: Physical Development: Gross and fine motor skills, coordination, and physical abilities
Personal/Social Development: Emotional regulation, social interactions, and self-care skills
Language Development: Communication, vocabulary, and understanding of language
Cognitive Development: Thinking, reasoning, problem-solving, and learning abilities

sections.title: Developmental Milestones by Age
sections.content: Here's what to expect at each stage of your child's development from ages 2-5:
points: Age 2: Kicks ball, walks stairs, plays alongside others, puts 2-4 word sentences together, sorts shapes and colors
Age 3: Climbs and runs, pedals tricycle, takes turns, expresses emotions, names familiar things, plays make-believe
Age 4: Catches balls, uses scissors, prefers social play, knows songs by memory, names colors and numbers
Age 5: Hops and swings, uses utensils, distinguishes real from pretend, speaks clearly, counts to 10, writes letters

sections.title: Supporting Healthy Development
sections.content: You can actively support your child's development through daily interactions and activities:
points: Provide plenty of opportunities for physical play and exploration
Encourage social interactions with peers through playdates and groups
Read together daily to build language and cognitive skills
Offer age-appropriate puzzles and games that challenge thinking
Create consistent routines that provide security and predictability
Praise effort and progress rather than just achievement

sections.title: When to Seek Guidance
points: Consult your pediatrician if your child shows delays in multiple areas
Trust your instincts - you know your child best
Early intervention can address developmental concerns effectively
Remember that children develop at different rates within normal ranges
Focus on overall progress rather than comparing to other children

content.headline: The 'Sleep, Baby & You' Approach: A New Way to Understand Infant Sleep
content.intro: The 'Sleep, Baby & You' program offers a revolutionary approach to infant sleep that focuses on parental well-being and realistic expectations rather than sleep training. Developed from the evidence-based Possums Sleep Program, this method helps parents understand normal infant sleep development while providing tools to manage fatigue and anxiety. Research shows this responsive approach leads to sustained positive changes in parental attitudes and sleep management strategies.

sections.title: The Challenge of Postpartum Fatigue and Infant Sleep
sections.content: Sleep disruption affects most new parents and can have significant impacts on mental health and family wellbeing:
points: 64-67% of women experience postpartum fatigue for up to 2 years after birth
Sleep disruption is linked to increased depression and anxiety in both parents
Parental fatigue can affect emotional stability, relationships, and daily functioning
Traditional sleep training often conflicts with responsive parenting approaches
Parents need support that aligns with their values and infant's needs

sections.title: The 'Sleep, Baby & You' Approach Explained
sections.content: This innovative program combines sleep science with psychological support to help families:
points: Recalibrate expectations of normal infant sleep development
Encourage responsive parenting and experimentation with different strategies
Support development of baby's biological sleep regulators naturally
Manage negative thinking and anxiety using Acceptance and Commitment Therapy
Promote parental wellbeing alongside infant sleep needs

sections.title: Key Principles of the Program
sections.content: The approach is built on several evidence-based foundations that distinguish it from traditional sleep training:
points: Evolutionary understanding of infant needs and sleep patterns
Integration of interdisciplinary sleep science research
Focus on parent-infant enjoyment and secure attachment
Empowerment through education about sleep science
Values-based approach to parenting decisions

sections.title: Proven Results from Field Testing
sections.content: Extensive testing with UK parents and practitioners demonstrated significant benefits:
points: 100% of parents who received the intervention implemented suggested changes
70% of changes were sustained for at least two weeks
Practitioners reported materials were easy to explain and parents understood them well
Approach aligned well with responsive parenting methods already in use
Parents found the suggestions practical and easy to follow in daily life

sections.title: Practical Strategies for Parents
sections.content: The program offers concrete tools that parents can implement immediately:
points: Understand and work with your baby's natural sleep regulators
Experiment with different approaches to find what works for your family
Manage anxiety and negative thoughts about sleep disruption
Balance meeting infant needs with parental self-care
Build confidence in responding to your baby's unique sleep patterns

sections.title: Why This Approach Works
points: Reduces parental stress by normalizing infant sleep patterns
Empowers parents to trust their instincts and their baby's cues
Provides realistic expectations rather than quick-fix solutions
Supports parental mental health alongside infant sleep
Fits with responsive, attachment-focused parenting values
Can be adapted to each family's unique circumstances and needs

content.headline: Newborn Feeding Guidelines: Preventing Early Overfeeding and Future Obesity
content.intro: Groundbreaking research reveals that overfeeding during the first day of life can significantly increase the risk of childhood obesity. Understanding appropriate feeding volumes and recognizing hunger cues are essential skills for new parents. Proper feeding practices established in the first days can set the foundation for lifelong healthy eating patterns and weight management.

sections.title: Critical First Day Feeding Research
sections.content: A study of 1,106 formula-fed infants found startling connections between early feeding and future weight:
points: 93% of newborns were overfed at least once on their first day
71% were overfed 3 or more times during their first 7 feeds
Overfeeding 5+ times increased obesity risk 5x at age 4
Consistent overfeeding all 7 feeds increased risk 7x at age 4
Early metabolic programming may establish lifelong patterns

sections.title: Appropriate Feeding Volumes by Weight
sections.content: Follow these evidence-based guidelines for newborn feeding amounts:
points: Avoid feeds greater than 30ml in single sessions initially
Start with 15-20ml per feeding for average weight newborns
Adjust amounts based on baby's weight and hunger cues
Feed every 2-3 hours or 8-12 times in 24 hours
Increase volume gradually as baby grows and demands

sections.title: Recognizing Hunger and Fullness Cues
sections.content: Learn to read your baby's signals to prevent overfeeding:
points: Early hunger signs: smacking lips, rooting, hand-to-mouth movements
Active hunger signs: crying, agitated movements, searching for nipple
Fullness signals: slowing sucking, turning away, relaxed hands
Stop feeding when baby shows satisfaction cues
Avoid using feeding as only comfort method

sections.title: Practical Prevention Strategies
sections.content: Implement these approaches to establish healthy feeding patterns:
points: Use smaller bottles (2oz/60ml) for first weeks to control portions
Pace bottle feeding with frequent breaks for burping
Focus on responsive feeding rather than scheduled amounts
Educate all caregivers about appropriate feeding volumes
Monitor weight gain patterns with healthcare provider

sections.title: Long-term Health Implications
points: Early overfeeding may program metabolism for weight gain
Obese infants are likely to remain overweight into adulthood
Establishing healthy patterns early prevents future struggles
Proper feeding supports optimal brain and physical development
Consult lactation consultants or feeding specialists for concerns

content.headline: Understanding Common Newborn Health Issues: Birth Injuries and Care
content.intro: Many newborns experience minor health concerns and birth injuries that, while often alarming to parents, are typically temporary and resolve without intervention. Understanding these common conditions helps parents provide appropriate care and know when to seek medical attention. Most birth-related issues are minor and part of the normal adjustment to life outside the womb.

sections.title: Common Birth Injuries and Their Causes
sections.content: Several factors can predispose infants to birth injuries, though most resolve spontaneously:
points: Maternal factors: Prolonged labor, preterm/postterm delivery, cephalopelvic disproportion
Fetal factors: Macrosomia, multiple gestation, abnormal presentation, congenital anomalies
Obstetric factors: Forceps delivery, vacuum extraction, cesarean birth
Monitoring procedures: Fetal scalp monitoring during labor
Often multiple factors combine to increase injury risk

sections.title: Head and Scalp Injuries
sections.content: The most common birth injuries involve the head and scalp during delivery:
points: Caput Succedaneum: Soft swelling that crosses suture lines, resolves in days
Cephalohematoma: Bleeding between skull and periosteum, stays within bone boundaries
Subgaleal Hemorrhage: Serious bleeding into scalp compartment, requires monitoring
Skull Fractures: Rare, usually linear or depressed 'Ping-Pong' type
Most require no treatment and resolve spontaneously

sections.title: Soft Tissue and Bone Injuries
sections.content: Other common injuries that typically heal without intervention:
points: Bruises and petechiae from pressure during delivery
Clavicle fractures - most common bone injury, heal with minimal intervention
Facial nerve paralysis from pressure, usually temporary
Brachial plexus injuries affecting arm movement
Subconjunctival hemorrhages - red eyes that resolve quickly

sections.title: Nursing Care and Parent Support
sections.content: Proper care and parental reassurance are essential for recovery:
points: Maintain asepsis of any broken skin to prevent infection
Provide careful handling and proper positioning for fractures
Monitor for complications like infection or excessive bleeding
Document injuries accurately for tracking resolution
Offer emotional support and education to concerned parents

sections.title: When to Seek Medical Attention
points: Signs of infection: Redness, swelling, fever, pus drainage
Neurological changes: Lethargy, seizures, abnormal movements
Respiratory distress: Breathing difficulties, cyanosis
Feeding problems: Inability to suck or swallow effectively
Persistent symptoms beyond expected resolution time

content.headline: First Trimester Exercise: Higher Activity Levels May Reduce Gestational Diabetes Risk
content.intro: New research reveals that exercise during the first trimester significantly reduces the risk of abnormal glucose screening and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). The study found that the amount of exercise needed to achieve these benefits may be higher than current recommendations, suggesting that more vigorous activity provides greater protection. Understanding these findings can help you make informed decisions about physical activity during early pregnancy.

sections.title: Key Research Findings
sections.content: A major study of 2,246 pregnant women (79% minorities) found significant benefits from first-trimester exercise:
points: Women exercising at the 75th percentile (≥264 minutes of moderate exercise weekly) had 4.8% lower risk of abnormal glucose screening
The same high-exercise group had 2.1% lower risk of developing gestational diabetes
24.3% of women had abnormal glucose screening results overall
Only 6.5% developed gestational diabetes in the study cohort
Benefits were observed after adjusting for pre-pregnancy BMI, exercise history, and weight gain

sections.title: Recommended Exercise Levels for Maximum Benefit
sections.content: The study suggests current recommendations might be insufficient for optimal diabetes prevention:
points: Current guidelines: ≥150 minutes of moderate exercise per week
Study recommendation: ≥264 minutes of moderate exercise per week (about 38 minutes daily)
This represents the 75th percentile of exercise in the study population
Vigorous exercise was also beneficial and considered safe for most women
Exercise volume combines intensity, duration, and frequency

sections.title: Types of Beneficial Exercise
sections.content: The study focused on intentional sports and exercise activities including:
points: Moderate-intensity activities: walking, swimming, weight lifting, resistance exercise
Vigorous-intensity activities: brisk hill walking, jogging
Activities performed specifically for fitness and health benefits
Combination exercises that include both cardiovascular and resistance elements
Daily lifestyle activities were considered separately from intentional exercise

sections.title: Why First Trimester Exercise Matters
sections.content: Early pregnancy exercise sets the foundation for metabolic health throughout pregnancy:
points: Helps establish healthy patterns before weight gain accelerates
May influence placental development and function
Supports glucose metabolism before insulin resistance increases
Can prevent excessive gestational weight gain
Sets positive habits for the remainder of pregnancy

sections.title: Practical Implementation Tips
points: Aim for at least 38 minutes of moderate exercise daily
Combine cardiovascular and resistance exercises
Continue pre-pregnancy exercise routines if medically approved
Monitor for any concerning symptoms and adjust accordingly
Consult your healthcare provider about appropriate exercise intensity
Track your activity to ensure you're meeting beneficial levels

content.headline: Managing Morning Sickness: Evidence-Based Strategies for Nausea Relief
content.intro: Morning sickness affects about 70% of pregnant women, typically beginning around 6 weeks and peaking between 8-10 weeks. While the name suggests morning-only symptoms, nausea and vomiting can occur at any time. Most cases improve by the second trimester, but effective management strategies can provide significant relief during the challenging first trimester.

sections.title: Understanding Morning Sickness Patterns
sections.content: Knowing what to expect can help you manage symptoms more effectively:
points: Starts around week 6 of pregnancy for most women
Peaks in intensity between weeks 8-10
Typically improves or resolves by week 13-14
Despite the name, can occur at any time of day
Symptoms range from mild nausea to frequent vomiting

sections.title: Dietary Strategies for Relief
sections.content: Simple changes to eating habits can significantly reduce nausea:
points: Eat crackers or dry toast before getting out of bed
Consume several small meals instead of three large ones
Avoid spicy, fatty, or strongly flavored foods
Choose bland foods: bananas, rice, applesauce, toast
Stay hydrated with water, ginger tea, or electrolyte drinks
Eat protein-rich snacks between meals

sections.title: Lifestyle Adjustments That Help
sections.content: Environmental and routine changes can minimize triggers:
points: Avoid strong odors that trigger nausea
Get plenty of rest and avoid exhaustion
Keep rooms well-ventilated or use a fan
Try fresh scents like lemon, mint, or orange
Don't lie down immediately after eating
Rinse mouth after vomiting to protect teeth

sections.title: When to Seek Medical Attention
sections.content: Some symptoms indicate a more serious condition called hyperemesis gravidarum:
points: Vomiting more than three times per day
Signs of dehydration: dark urine, dizziness, reduced urination
Weight loss of 10 pounds or more
Inability to keep any food or liquids down
Brown or bloody vomit
Extreme fatigue or confusion

sections.title: Medical Treatment Options
sections.content: When lifestyle changes aren't enough, these options can help:
points: Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplements
Doxylamine (available over-the-counter)
Prescription medication Diclegis® for severe cases
IV fluids for dehydration in hospital settings
Other anti-nausea medications as prescribed
Never use marijuana for morning sickness relief

sections.title: Risk Factors for Severe Morning Sickness
points: Pregnant with multiples (twins, triplets)
Personal or family history of severe morning sickness
History of motion sickness or migraines
Overweight before pregnancy
High stress or anxiety levels
Working night shifts or being sleep-deprived
